utterances: Yeah, kind of.
You know, I think that I never really stopped to think I would have, you know, whatever we claim as normalcy.
I would see my friends getting married and think, good for them.
I've got all these things I got to do, and that's OK if that's not for me.
And then it happened.
It happened to me, you know.
This album is - it's quite different from your previous work.
It's more pop than it is folk.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
Is that something you did on purpose?
Well, it's funny.
I don't know if I meant to, you know?
I had all this time, you know, after I sort of went through the thyroid breakdown and debacle.
And I really enjoyed playing music in such a different way coming out of that season.
And so it caused me to write tunes in a different meter.
More handclaps - you know, there was just more joy to be had.
Well, let's listen to the song ""Over the Moon,"" from the album ""With Love."" It's - I mean, it's one of my favorites.
Oh, mine, too.
Mine, too.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""OVER THE MOON"")
(Singing) When I think of your love, it puts a joy in my step.
The way you play with my heart makes me your instrument.
When I'm walking with you, feels like I'm walking on clouds.
I always feel up just by you being around 'cause you fill me with love.
Yeah, you fill me with love.
You fill me with love...
It's such a great pop song.
Yeah, isn't that awesome?
I wrote that.
I've often heard that it's easier to write about, you know, pain and heartbreak...
Oh, yeah.
Yes.
...than it is to write about love and happiness.
Is it true?
Yeah.
In my opinion, it's true.
I mean, listen, I wear my heart on my sleeve.
You know, my entire life, I've been trying to build people up, trying to build myself up.
It's a lot easier to do that when you're - when you've got the sorrow going.
Boy, can you really say some cool things, you know.
This boy said to me after a show, when he found out I was getting married.
He said Rosie, can I ask you something?
I said, you've got it.
He said, are you going to write the same kind of tunes now that you're getting married?
I said, don't you worry.
I'm still totally depressed.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
And he said, awesome.
I said, yeah!
And we high-fived, you know.
Sam said to me - Sam Beam, when I did the Iron & Wine tour - he said, do you find it harder to write songs now that, you know, you're married, and now that you fell in love?
I said yeah, it's different.
But, you know, it's cool.
It gives me a different repertoire.
So if I fall in love, then I know what that feels like now, and I can sing about it because I actually know what it feels like.
And I want it for everybody else, too.
It's not clear whether she has symptoms or not.
But any contact, you have to follow up for 21 days.
So what are the different ranges of responses that you could have for this person if she does in fact have symptoms?
From through the rest of the caucuses, that we will run only the ads that talk about why I should be president and not why Mitt Romney should not.
I know that some of you are saying that well, did you really have an ad?
I'm going to show you the ad.
You'll get a chance to find out exactly what we're doing.
(Soundbite of laughter)
No, I want you to see it.
Okay, so here's Mike Huckabee saying, okay, I'm not going to air these ads, but I'm not going to play it for all you reporters anyway.
Exactly.
And he proceeded to play this attack ad for us.
(Soundbite of campaign ad)
I approved this message because Iowans have a right to know the truth about Mitt Romney's dishonest attacks on me and even an American hero, John McCain.
And, Melissa, you kind of hear the laughter in the room.
They're playing this ad in one of those giant projection screens for all of us to see.
Dozen of cameras, the national media, TV, radio, newspaper, everybody there.
So this ad is clearly getting out there.
And it was very a bizarre moment.
You wouldn't have to be too cynical to say Mike Huckabee is having it both ways here.
First question was, Governor, isn't this hypocritical?
You say you're taking the high road, that you're not going to go negative, but here you are playing this ad for all of us.
Here's Huckabee's answer.
Well, by the same token, if I came and said, we were going to run an ad but we're not going to run an ad, you'd say where's the ad?
So I want to show you, we were fully prepared.
Frankly, you can call the television stations and find out that this was in their traffic.
You can also find out that we pulled it this morning.
And so, you know, if people want to be cynical about it, they can be cynical about it.
Well, Don, what was the reaction from former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney to all of these?

They quickly sent out e-mails to all of us essentially saying this is just kind of, you know, ludicrous, this Huckabee press conference and, again, the Romney campaign's spin on it is that this represents a Huckabee meltdown; further evidence that he's not ready to be president.
Okay.
NPR's Don Gonyea in Des Moines.
Don, thanks very much.
A pleasure.
The race for president is not the only one that's taking shape.
The terms of 34 senators and every member of the House are up in 2008.
And a number of lawmakers - many of them Republicans - have decided not to run again.
That's making Democrats upbeat about their chances to increase their margin in Congress.
Amy Walter is the editor of The Hotline from the National Journal, and she joins me now.
Republican Senator Pete Domenici from New Mexico was the latest to announce his retirement last week, a string of retirements we've seen in the recent months.
Just bring us up to date, who else is leaving and where are the tightest races?
Well, he was the latest and not totally unexpected.
But we've also seen retirements in places like Colorado, where Wayne Allard is deciding not to come back.
John Warner in Virginia, which is probably the most problematic seat for the Republicans, because another Warner, Mark Warner, former governor, is running there.
Chuck Hagel, also mentioned as a potential 2008 presidential candidate, announced he's not running for reelection in Nebraska.
And we know that, of course, even as Larry Craig is staying for the remainder of his term, he is not running for reelection.
In some cases, the Republicans that are leaving have announced health concerns - John Warner, Pete Domenici.
But for so many others, why are they stepping away at this moment?
If you were thinking about getting out at any time - and to find the excuse to do something different, you certainly have it in this kind of environment.
There's nothing out there right now for Republicans that gives them all that much hope looking at 2008.
We've been talking about the Republicans.
Are there any vulnerable Democrats in the sense?
Well, this is interesting.
There are no Democrats who've announced their retirement yet.
And on the side of vulnerable seats, you have to look at Mary Landrieu down in Louisiana who's had two very, very close elections contest.
I don't doubt that she'll have another one.
She doesn't have an opponent officially.
But we know, simply because of the demographics of Louisiana and most recently because of Hurricane Katrina that this will be a very different race for her.
South Dakota's another place where we're looking.
Tim Johnson, the senator there, coming back from a brain injury.
We don't know for 100 percent sure that he will stay in this race.
But that is another state that typically has had very competitive contest.
But he doesn't have a serious top-tier opponent yet.
And beyond the open seats, there are also a number of competitive, tight - potentially tight Republican seats as well.
Coming into 2008, Republicans knew they already had a bad hand that they were dealt.
They have more seats up than the Democrats - 22 to just 12 for the Democrats.
And they knew that a lot of their seats were in the blue states, like New Hampshire and Maine and Minnesota.
Those are all tough places regardless of how strong your incumbent is.
Then put on top of it a president who's struggling, an unpopular war, that all added up to trouble.
Now, you open up some seats.

And even though these aren't red states, Republicans have gotten some very good candidates and they're waiting, still, for one - a couple of other big names, really, the one that everybody's watching for is Bob Kerrey, the former governor, former senator from Nebraska.
If you listen to the Democrats, they're sounding pretty confident right now.
And part of that is not just the board in the way it's lining up, but also the money gap between the Democrats and the Republicans.
It sounds that the Democrats are far out earning the Republicans.
As of now, the only thing we could do is to identify them early when they still have strength to walk.
